chapter.title: Agents
chapter.para:
Jolokia is an agent based approach to JMX, which requires to install an extra piece of software, the agent. This software either needs to be deployed on the target server which should be accessed via remote JMX (). Or it can be installed on a dedicated proxy server (). For both operational modes, there exist four different kind of agents
Although the proxy mode is available for all four agents, you are normally free to setup the proxy environment. The recommendation here is the war-agent for which very lightweight servlet container exists. Tomcat or Jetty are both a perfect choice for a Jolokia proxy server.
.

varlistentry.listitem: This agent is packaged as a JEE Webarchive (War). It is the standard installation artifact for Java webapplicaton and problem one of the best known deployment format. Jolokia ships with an war-agent, which can be deployed like any other web application. This agent has been tested on a wealth of JEE servers, well known market leaders and more seldom species.

OSGi is a middleware specification focussing on modularity and a well defined dynamic lifecycle
Of course, there is much more on OSGi, a platform and programing model which I really like. So to say, this is my personal pet agent ;-).
. The Jolokia OSGi agent bundles comes in two flavors: One minimal one with the dependency on a running OSGi HttpService, and a all-in-one bundle including an embedded HttpServer (which is not exported). The former is the recommended, puristic solution, the later is provided for a quick startup for initial testing the OSGi agent (but should be replaced with the minimal bundle for production setups).

Mule is one of the leading Open Source Enterprise Service Bus (ESB). It provides a management api into which a dedicated Jolokia agent plugs in nicely. This agent includes an embedded Jetty for providing JMX HTTP access.

Starting with Java 6 the JDK provided by Sun (now Oracle) contains a lightweight HTTP-Server which is used e.g. for reference WebService stack included in Java 6. Together with the Java-agent API (normally used by profilers and other development tools requiring the instrumentation during class loading phase), the JVM 6 Jolokia agent is the most generic one. It is able to instrument any Java application running on a Sun/Oralce JDK 6
You could even instrument a JEE application server this way, however this is not recommended.
. It is fully feature, however tends to be a bit slow since the provided HTTP-Server is not optimized for performance. However it is useful for servers like Hadoop or Teracotta which does not provide a convenient hook for an HTTP exporting agent.
